DESCRIPTION
The command flac-sync is like rsync but specialized for flac files. flac-sync can synchronize added tags from one tree of flacs to another. It verifies that the audio is equal using length and md5-sum of the audio-part of the track. There are a wide range of options when and how to make synchronization or not. flac-sync has the possibility to do bidirectional synchronization.
OPTIONS
The program follows the usual GNU command line syntax, with long options starting with two dashes (`-'). A summary of options is included below.
The following options does not change the files:
-h
--help
Show summary of options.
-v
--verbose
Increase output verbosity.
-a
--audio
Tell when audio parts differ.
-d
--dry
Dry run, only tell what would have been done.
The following options affects how data is changed:
-b
--both
Synchronize in both directions, bidirectional sync.
-c
--copy
Copy files from source if missing in destination or audiopart differs. If combined with -t is it only copied if source is newer then destination. If combined with -b and -t newest replace oldest file.
-t
--time
If a tag exist in both src and dest and differ, src is only copied to dest if src is newer than dest. If combined with -b the newest files tag is preserved.
-o
--overwrite
If a tag exist in both src and dest and differ. src value is copied to dest. Cannot be combined with -t.
BUGS
When doing bidirectional syncronization (-b) files only existing in destination tree are ignored.
SEE ALSO
flac-diff 1 , flac-merge 1
See also the algorithm description in the documentation directory for details how flac-sync works.
